newsitem.title: ITALY: SOCCER-SACCHI URGES MILAN FANS TO HELP THE TEAM.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-SACCHI URGES MILAN FANS TO HELP THE TEAM.

text.p: AC Milan coach Arrigo Sacchi, appealed to supporters on Tuesday to help the struggling Italian champions and avoid rowdy behaviour.
"I'll be frank," the former Italy coach told a news conference. "For the final weeks of the season I'm asking all the fans to help: I don't want them to join the rabble."
Angry Milan fans bombarded their team's goal with flares, bottles and smoke bombs on Sunday when city rivals Inter took a 3-0 lead against Milan at San Siro.
The trouble could cost the club, beaten the previous week 6-1 by league leaders Juventus, heavily in fines.
Club chairman Silvio Berlusconi said later that the incidents were "rude and unworthy of a club that dominated the world for 10 years and has given great satisfaction to true fans.
"On Sunday the fans were rude and uncouth."
Sacchi, who took over as coach late last year after Uruguayan Oscar Washington Tabarez resigned, defended his players and said they deserved better.
"This club and these players have defined the most triumphant nine years in the history of Milan and maybe of soccer, and they deserve respect.
"Those who love Milan should show it now."
Milan, three times winners of the European Cup in the last decade and with four league titles in the past five years, are 12th in the league and fighting for a place in Europe.
Sacchi refused to comment on his future at the club, despite persistent rumours that Real Madrid coach Fabio Capello is poised to return to his former employers.
"I'm not interested in rumours and hearsay," Sacchi said.

Newspapers, reporting that Capello was likely to meet Berlusconi in Milan next week during a holiday in Italy, quoted him as saying on Tuesday that Capello would decide his own future and doubted he would return to Milan soon.
"I don't think Capello will leave Madrid if they win the title and have the chance of the European Cup," he said.
Berlusconi added that he had no need to confirm Sacchi in his job because he had a signed contract.
